questions.Question: In Bengal, the East India Company's headquarters were located at
questions.solution: Solution:		The headquarters of East India Company were located at Fort William in Bengal. Fort William is a fort built in Calcutta (presently Kolkata) on the eastern banks of the River Hooghly, the major distributary of the River Ganges, during the early years of the Bengal Presidency of British India. It was named after King William III of England. In front of the Fort is the Maidan, which used to be a part of the Fort and is the largest urban park in Calcutta.

questions.Question: Who established the Sadr-Di-wani-Adalat during the British East India Company's rule?
questions.solution: Solution:		Sadr-Di-wani-Adalat during Mughal and British rule in India was a High Court of Civil and Revenue matters.The Ṣadr Dīwānī ʿAdālat was the Supreme Court of Revenue in British India established at Calcutta by Warren Hastings in 1772. It was reformed in 1780 and again in 1793 by the British Parliament.

questions.Question: In 1612 __________established a trading post in Gujarat
questions.solution: Solution:		British established a trading post in 1612 at Gujarat.

questions.Question: After the commencement of the government of India Act-1858, what name was to British Governor-General of India?
questions.solution: Solution:		After the commencement of the government of India Act-1858, Viceroy of the state was to British Governor-General of India.

questions.Question: Author of Poverty and Un-British Rule in India is__________
questions.solution: Solution:		Naoroji Dadabhai Is the author of books such as Poverty and Un-British Rule In India.

questions.Question: Which of the following events made the English East India Company the legitimate masters of the Bengal Suba?
questions.solution: Solution:		English East India Company became the legitimate masters of Bengal Suba after battle of Buxar which was held on 22 Oct, 1764 between East lndia company led by Hector Munro and Mir Qasim (Nawab of Bengal), Mughal emperor Shah Alam, Nawab of Avadh Shira-jud-daula.

questions.Question: Which of the following Government of India Act introduced the diarchy system in the provinces of India?
questions.solution: Solution:		Dyarchy, also spelled diarchy, system of double government introduced by the Government of India Act (1919) for the provinces of British India. Dyarchy was introduced as a constitutional reform by Edwin Samuel Montagu (secretary of state for India, 1917–22) and Lord Chelmsford (viceroy of India, 1916–21).

questions.Question: Nana Sahib the adopted son of Peshwa Baji Rao II had become a great enemy of the British because
questions.optionC: The British had stopped his pension
questions.optionD: His estate had been snatched from him
questions.solution: Solution:		Nana Saheb was the adopted son of Peshwa Baji Rao II. His annual pension was stopped because the British refused to recognize him as the legitimate heir to the throne as he was adopted.

questions.Question: British Prime Minister Attlee made the historic announcement of the end of British rule in India (and transfer of power to responsible Indian hands by a date not later than June1948) on
questions.solution: Solution:		The Prime Minister of the United Kingdom announced on 20 February 1947 that: the British Government would grant full self-government to British India by 30 June 1948 at the latest, The future of the Princely States would be decided after the date of final transfer is decided.

questions.Question: The Viceroy who wanted to train Indian in the art of selfgovernment was
questions.solution: Solution:		Ripon was a true democrat. He took some steps towards liberalizing the administration in India. His aim was to give popular and political education to the Indians. He formulated the local self government and laid the foundations of representative institutions in India.

questions.Question: When the East India Company was formed, the Mughal emperor in India was
questions.solution: Solution:		The East India Company was incorporated by royal charter on December 31, 1600. It was an English company formed for the exploitation of trade with East and Southeast Asia and India during the reign of Mughal Emperor Akbar (1556-1605).

questions.Question: The British India Society was formed in __________
questions.solution: Solution:		The British India Society (1839): Founded in London with the efforts of William Adam, one of the friends of Raja Ram Mohan Roy. He along with George Thompson, William Ednis, and Major General Briggs organised meetings and enlightened people about the miserable conditions in India.

questions.Question: When the Congress Ministries were formed in the provinces in June 1937, the Viceroy of India was
questions.solution: Solution:		The All-India Muslim League failed to form the government in any province. The Congress ministries resigned in October and November 1939, in protest against Viceroy Lord Linlithgow's action of declaring India to be a belligerent in the Second World War without consulting the Indian people.

questions.Question: The first Mysore War Fought between the British and Hyder Ali in 1767- 1769 A.D., came to an end by the
questions.solution: Solution:		In 1767 Mysore was a powerful state under Hyder Ali. In 1769, the first Anglo-Mysore war was fought in which Haider Ali defeated the British and Treaty of Madras was signed between them. Haider Ali occupied almost the whole of Carnatic.

questions.Question: The British Government intervened in the affairs of the Company and passed an Act in 1773 A.D., known as the
questions.solution: Solution:		Regulating Act, (1773), legislation passed by the British Parliament for the regulation of the British East India Company's Indian territories, mainly in Bengal. The act was amended and the government of India was recast by Prime Minister William Pitt's India Act of 1784.

questions.Question: __________ started an all-India campaign for restoring the entrance age of 21 and for simultaneous ICS examination in India
questions.solution: Solution:		S.N. Banerjee started an all-India campaign for restoring the entrance age of 21 and for simultaneous ICS examination in India.

questions.Question: Who among the following Viceroys became a victim of one of the convicts during his visit to the Andamans?
questions.solution: Solution:		Lord Mayo was stabbed when he was in Andamans. He was first and last Viceory murdered in India.

questions.Question: India was granted freedom during the British Prime Minister
questions.solution: Solution:		Indian Independence Act 1947 passed on 1st August 1947 by the British Parliament in reign of Prime minister Clement Attlee (Labour party). On 14 August 1947 India divided into two dominion states Pakistan (14th August) and India (15th August).

questions.Question: By the Charter Act of 1813 the Indian trade except in __________ was thrown open to all British subjects
questions.solution: Solution:		Charter act of 1813 ended the monopoly of the East India Company in India, however the company's monopoly in trade with china and trade in tea with India was kept intact. Thus, trade with India for all commodities except Tea was thrown open to all British subjects.

questions.Question: Before the Regulating Act was passed in 1773, there was __________ at home to administer the East India Company
questions.solution: Solution:		Before the Regulating Act was passed in 1773, there was A Committee of 24 at home to, administer the East India Company.

questions.Question: The State Jhansi was made a part of the British Empire in India through
questions.solution: Solution:		Lord Dalhousie introduced the Doctrine of Lapse i.e any princely state under the direct influence of East India Company, as a vassal state under the British SubsidiarySystem wouldautomatically be annexed if the ruler was either"manifestly in competent or died without a male heir.The series of state annexed - Satara, Jaipur, Sambhal pur, Jhansi (1854).

questions.Question: The first strategically placed factory that the Britishers had fortified was at
questions.solution: Solution:		Englishmen’s easy success in trade and in establishing independent and fortified settlements at Madras and at Bombay, and the preoccupation of Aurangzeb with the anti-Maratha campaigns led the English to abandon the role of humble petitioners.

questions.Question: Who convinced the British in 1829 to outlaw Sati?
questions.solution: Solution:		Raja Ram Mohan Roy convinced the British in 1829 to outlaw Sati.

questions.Question: The Vernacular Press Act was passed in __________
questions.solution: Solution:		The act was proposed by Lord Lytton, then Viceroy of India, and was unanimously passed by the Viceroy's Council on 14 March 1878.

questions.Question: Mahatma Gandhi gave up the title of Kaiser-i-Hind and returned all the war medals which were awarded to him by the British for his war services (during the First World War)
questions.optionA: in protest against the Jallianwala Bagh tragedy
questions.optionC: in support of the Khilafat demand when the Central Khilafat Committee organised a general all-India hartal on August 1, 1920
questions.solution: Solution:		Mahatma Gandhi gave up the title of Kaiser-i-Hind and returned all the war medals which were awarded to him by the British for his war services (during the First World War) in support of the Khilafat demand when the Central Khilafat Committee organised a general all-India hartal on August 1, 1920.

questions.Question: In the 18th Century the Royal prerogative in the affairs of the East India Company was controlled by
questions.solution: Solution:		In the 18th Century the Royal prerogative in the affairs of the East India Company was controlled byThe Parliament in England.

questions.Question: In March 1942, British Prime Minister Winston Churchill appointed the Cripps Mission to resolve Indian political crisis because
questions.optionA: he was under pressure from the US President Roosevelt
questions.optionB: of the gravity of the Japanese war menace on India's borders
questions.optionD: of INA's initial success on India's eastern borders
questions.solution: Solution:		In March 1942, British Prime Minister Winston Churchill appointed the Cripps Mission to resolve Indian political crisis because he was under pressure from the US President Roosevelt and of the gravity of the Japanese war menace on India's borders.

questions.Question: As the unrest continued unabatedly, the Madras government appointed . . . . . . the collector of Malabar as special commissioner to enquire into the causes of the uprisings and recommend remedial measures.
questions.solution: Solution:		William Logan (1841–1914) was a Scottish officer of the Madras Civil Service under the British Government. Before his appointment as Collector of Malabar, he had served in the area for about twenty years in the capacity of Magistrate and Judge. He was conversant in Malayalam, Tamil and Telugu.

questions.Question: Which of the following British Prime Minister headed the First Round Table Conference in London?
questions.solution: Solution:		The Round Table Conference officially inaugurated by George V on November 12, 1930 in Royal Gallery House of Lords at London and chaired by the British Prime Minister, Ramsay MacDonald. The three British political parties were represented by sixteen delegates.

questions.Question: In 1661 the company obtained __________ from Charles II
questions.solution: Solution:		On 11 May 1661, the marriage treaty of Charles II of England and Catherine of Braganza, daughter of King John IV of Portugal, placed Bombay in the possession of the British Empire, as part of Catherine's dowry to Charles.

questions.Question: The Vernacular Press Act was repealed by __________
questions.solution: Solution:		Vernacular Press Act, in British India, law enacted in 1878 to curtail the freedom of the Indian-language (i.e., non-English) press. The law was repealed in 1881 by Lytton's successor as viceroy, Lord Ripon (governed 1880-84).

questions.Question: By which Charter Act, the East India Company's monopoly of trade with China come to an end?
questions.solution: Solution:		Charter Acts of 1813 was an Act of the Parliament of the United Kingdom which renewed the charter issued to the British East India Company, and continued the Company's rule in India. However, the Company's commercial monopoly was ended, except for the tea trade and the trade with China. The Charter Act of 1833 ended the monopoly in trade with China and the monopoly to trade in tea in India.

questions.Question: Which of the following is not among the regions where the Britishers had first set up trading posts?
questions.solution: Solution:		Goa is not among the regions where the Britishers had first set up trading posts.

questions.Question: Who propounded the theory of 'Economic Drain of India' during British imperialism?
questions.solution: Solution:		Dadabhai Naoroji's work focused on the drain of wealth from India to England during colonial rule of British in India. One of the reasons that the Drain theory is attributed to Naoroji is his decision to estimate the net national profit of India, and by extension, the effect that colonisation has on the country.

questions.Question:
Who among the following who fought against British in 1857 Revolt?
I. Kunwar Singh
II. Tantia Tope
III. Nana Saheb
IV. Maulavi Ahmaduallah
questions.solution: Solution:		All of these four leaders fought against British in 1857 Revolt -Kunwar Singh- Bihar, Tanitia Tope- Gwalior, Nana Saheb- Kanpur, Maulavi Ahmaduallah- Faizabad.

questions.Question: Which Government of India Act/Charter Act generated the post of Governor-General of India?
questions.solution: Solution:		Governor-General of Bengal was made Governor-General of India through the Charter Act of 1833. Under this provision Lord William Bentinck became the first Governor-General of India. It deprived the Governors of Bombay and Madras of their legislative powers. For the first time, the Governor-General's Government was known as the 'Government of India' and his council as the 'India Council' in 1858.

questions.Question: In 1831 Bentinck signed a treaty with Ranjit Singh to protect the British territories from
questions.solution: Solution:		In 1831 Bentinck signed a treaty with Ranjit Singh to protect the British territories from Russian menace.

questions.Question: As a result of the partition of Bengal announced by Lord Curzon in 1905, Bengal was partitioned into two provinces of
questions.optionD: Bengal and Odisha and East Bengal and Assam
questions.solution: Solution:		As a result of the partition of Bengal announced by Lord Curzon in 1905, Bengal was partitioned into two provinces of Bengal and Eastern Bengal & Assam.

questions.Question: Regulating Act was in the year of__________
questions.solution: Solution:		Regulating Act, (1773), legislation passed by the British Parliament for the regulation of the British East India Company's Indian territories, mainly in Bengal.

questions.Question: The Governor General of India who initiated the introduction of English in India was
questions.solution: Solution:		In India Lord Macaulay (Thomas Balington Macaulay) is fully credited with the official introduction of English education though the necessary order on the subject were given by Lord William Bentinck the governor general of India on 7th March 1835.

questions.Question: Who made remarkable contribution to the development of Local government?
questions.solution: Solution:		Lord Ripon made remarkable contribution to the development of local government. In 1882, he abandoned the existing system of local government by the officially nominated people.

questions.Question: Lord Mountbatten had replaced Lord __________ as the viceroy of India in 1947
questions.solution: Solution:		Lord Mountbatten had replaced Lord Wavell as the viceroy of India in 1947.

questions.Question: The First Opium War started__________
questions.solution: Solution:		The First Opium War, fought over opium trade, financial reparations, and diplomatic status, began in 1839 and was concluded by the Treaty of Nanking (Nanjing) in 1842.

questions.Question: Which of the following act led to the introduction of dual system of government in India?
questions.solution: Solution:		Pitt's India Act 1784 or the East India Company Act 1784 was passed in the British Parliament to rectify the defects of the Regulating Act 1773. It resulted in dual control or joint government in India by Crown in Great Britain and the British East India Company, with crown having ultimate authority.

questions.Question: What was the motive of Lord Wellesley to introduced the system of Subsidiary Alliance?
questions.optionA: Improve the administration of the Indian States
questions.optionC: Tone up the British Indian administration
questions.optionD: Prevent the French influence in the Indian States
questions.solution: Solution:		Wellesley’s aims were expansionism and imperialism. He wan­ted to expand the British dominions in India to such an extent that it should become the sovereign power in India. His expansionist mind would not remain content with British remaining one of the powers in India, as such he set himself to the task of converting India into an empire of Britain. Another aim, which was ancillary to his main objective, was removal of French influence from India and to make possibility of French territorial expansion of India impossible.

questions.Question: Who was the first Indian to be elected to the British Parliament?
questions.solution: Solution:		Dadabhai Naroji was the first Anglo Indian to elect the British Parliament. He also known as Grand Old Man of India. He introduced, drain of wealth theory.

questions.Question: The first interim government during the British rule in India was formed in
questions.solution: Solution:		On 2nd September 1946 the Interim Government of India was formed. This temporary government was formed from the Constituent Assembly of India (which was then newly elected). This government was entrusted the task of helping the transition of India and Pakistan from British rule to Independence as two separate nations.

questions.Question: The English rounded Calcutta after obtaining the zamindari of three villages, viz Sutanuti, Kalikata and Govindpur, from the Mughal Viceroy of Bengal in 1698. The nucleus of the British settlement in Calcutta was
questions.solution: Solution:		the english rounded calcutta after obtaining the zamindari of three villages, viz sutanuti, kalikata and govindpur, from the mughal viceroy of bengal in 1698. The nucleus of the british settlement in calcutta was Fort William.

questions.Question: The inauguration of the Ganapati and Shivaji Festivals was done by
questions.solution: Solution:		The inauguration of the Ganapati and Shivaji Festivals was done by 1895.

questions.Question: __________, a judge of the Supreme Court founded the Asiatic society of Bengal in 1784 A.D.
questions.solution: Solution:		The Asiatic Society was founded by civil servant Sir William Jones on 15 January 1784 in a meeting presided over by Sir William Jones, Justice of the Supreme Court of Judicature at Fort William at the Fort William in Calcutta, then capital of the British Raj, to enhance and further the cause of Oriental research.

questions.Question: The Ilbert Bill introduced In Lord Ripon's reign is significant because
questions.optionA: it limited the Britishers political authority
questions.optionB: it put restrictions on the vernacular press
questions.optionC: it debarred Indians from entering the civil services
questions.optionD: it removed racial discrimination from the judicial services
questions.solution: Solution:		The introduction of the bill led to intense opposition in Britain and from British settlers in India that ultimately played on racial tension before it was enacted in 1884 in a severely compromised state. The bitter controversy deepened antagonism between the British and Indians and was a prelude to the formation of the Indian National Congress in the next two years. There was also a strong protest among Europeans.

questions.Question: Who was the supreme body in the Britain at the time of commencement of the Government of India Act- 1858?
questions.solution: Solution:		The British Parliament was the supreme body in the Britain at the time of commencement of the Government of India Act- 1858.

questions.Question: Which of the following is not correct about Montegu- Chelmsford's Reform & Government of India Act, 1919?
questions.optionA: It changed the administrative system in India
questions.optionB: In this Act the central legislative council was replaced by two houses-the imperial legislative assembly and the council of state
questions.optionC: Education and public health were placed under charge of ministers responsible to the legislature
questions.optionD: All of the above are incorrect
questions.solution: Solution:		The Montagu–Chelmsford Reforms or more briefly known as Mont-Ford Reforms were reforms introduced by the colonial government in British India to introduce self-governing institutions gradually to India. The reforms take their name from Edwin Samuel Montagu, the Secretary of State for India during the latter parts of World War I and Lord Chelmsford, Viceroy of India between 1916 and 1921. The reforms were outlined in the Montagu-Chelmsford Report prepared in 1918 and formed the basis of the Government of India Act 1919.

questions.Question: Which of the following is not the part of Government of India Act, 1935
questions.optionA: This act provided for setting up of the federation of India comprising British Indian provinces
questions.optionB: Diarchy in the provinces was replaced by provincial autonomy
questions.optionC: The post of Indian council of secretary of state for India made permanent
questions.optionD: The diarchy was introduced at the centre
questions.solution: Solution:		The first Secretary of state was Lord Stanley, who prior to 2 August 1858, served as President of the Board of Control. The Secretary of State was now the political head of the India.

questions.Question: Which of the following is not the provision of government of India act, 1935?
questions.optionA: This act ended the system of diarchy
questions.optionB: The structure for "Federation of India" was established for both British India and some or all of the "princely states"
questions.optionC: Burma became the part of India
questions.optionD: The introduction of direct elections, thus increasing the franchise from seven million to thirty-five million people
questions.solution: Solution:		The British colony of Burma was part of the British run-state in India, the Empire of India, from 1824 to 1937. It is not the provision of government of India act, 1935.

questions.Question: Warren Hastings was appointed as the Governor of __________ in 1772
questions.solution: Solution:		Warren Hastings (6 December 1732 – 22 August 1818), an English statesman, was the first Governor of the Presidency of Fort William (Bengal), the head of the Supreme Council of Bengal, and thereby the first de facto Governor-General of India from 1772 to 1785.

questions.Question: The Company lost all its administrative powers__________
questions.optionA: By the Government of India Act of 1658
questions.optionB: By the Government of India Act of 1758
questions.optionC: By the Government of India Act of 1858
questions.optionD: By the Government of India Act of 1958
questions.solution: Solution:		British Parliament brought the Government of India Act, 1858, which made the following changes: i. Transferred powers from the East India Company to the Crown. ii. A member of British Parliament was made secretary of state of India to exercise powers on behalf of the Crown and was responsible to the British Parliament. iii. The Governor General for India was provided with an Executive Council, whose decision he was empowered to override.

questions.Question: The momentous decision to transfer the capital from Calcutta to Delhi, to annul the partition of Bengal and to abolish Indian indentured labour were taken during the Viceroyalty of Lord
questions.solution: Solution:		At that time, Lord Hardinge was the Governor General of the British held territories in India, and he was the one that shifted the capital of India from Calcutta to Delhi.

questions.Question: Till the end of the 17th Century the growth of the executive and legislative powers of the East india Company depended on
questions.solution: Solution:		Till the end of the 17th Century the growth of the executive and legislative powers of the East India Company depended on Crown.

questions.Question: In November 1781, Sir Eyre Coote defeated __________ at Porto Nova
questions.solution: Solution:		The Battle of Porto Novo was fought on 1 July 1781 between forces of the Kingdom of Mysore and British East India Company in the place called Porto Novo (now known as Parangipettai) on the Indian subcontinent, during the Second Anglo-Mysore War. The British force, numbering more than 8,000 under the command of Sir Eyre Coote defeated a force estimated at 40,000 under the command of Hyder Ali.

questions.Question: The English East Company achieved a major victory over the Portuguese in the Battle of __________ in 1612
questions.solution: Solution:		The naval Battle of Swally, also known as Battle of Suvali, took place on 29–30 November 1612 off the coast of Suvali (anglicised to Swally) a village near the Surat city (now in Gujarat, India) and was a victory for four English East India Company galleons over four Portuguese galleons and 26 barks (rowing vessels with no armament).

questions.Question: Who was the Governor General of India during the Civil Disobedience Movement?
questions.solution: Solution:		Lord Irwin was the Governor General and Viceroy of India (1926-1931). On April 3, 1926 Lord Irwin was appointed 30th Viceroy and Governor-General of India. This was the most tumultuous period for the politics of India.

questions.Question: Who tried to rediscover India's past?
questions.solution: Solution:		Max Muller

questions.Question: The process of the introduction of education in English had been initiated in India by Lord
questions.solution: Solution:		Thomas Babington Macaulay was the secretary to the Board of control of India during the British rule. He was the secretary under Lord Grey from 1832 to 1833. He is known for his Minute on Indian Education which came out in February 1835. He wanted to teach English to the people of India and not Sanskrit or Persian.

questions.Question:
Select the correct chronological sequence of the following events?
I. Appointment of the Simon Commission.
II. Formation of the first Labour Government in Britain.
III. Submission of the Nehru report.
IV. Inauguration of the First Round Table Conference
questions.solution: Solution:		I. Appointment of the Simon Commission - November 1927 II. Formation of the first Labour Government in Britain - January 1924 III. Submission of the Nehru report - August 1928 IV. Inauguration of the First Round Table Conference - November 1930

questions.Question: What was meant by the secretary of State of India during the British?
questions.optionA:
An official who worked as the Secretary to the
Viceroy of India
questions.optionB:
A Secretary level official appointed in each
Presidency of India
questions.optionC:
A British minister given full control over the
Government of India
questions.optionD:
A senior officer appointed the Viceroy to look
into his internal administration in India
questions.solution: Solution:		Secretary of State is also deemed as Political Head of India. The post was created in Charter Act of 1858. The first Secretary of state was Lord Stanley.

questions.Question: Dadabhai Naoroji's book 'poverty and un British rule in India' published in __________ analysed the nature of the British rule in India
questions.solution: Solution:		Naoroji published Poverty and un-British Rule in India in 1901. It analysed the nature of the British rule in India.

questions.Question: Who among the British Governor- General shown great interest in the preservation of ancient monuments?
questions.solution: Solution:		The British Governor- General Lord Curzon shown great interest in the preservation of ancient monuments.

questions.Question: When the East India Company was established India was ruled by
questions.solution: Solution:		When the East India Company was established India was ruled by a Mughal Emperor.

questions.Question: Who among the following revolutionaries was executed by the British
questions.solution: Solution:		Shivaram Hari Rajguru (24 August 1908 – 23 March 1931) was an Indian revolutionary from Maharashtra, known mainly for his involvement in the assassination of a British Raj police officer.

questions.Question: During the Second World War the British forces were defeated at __________
questions.solution: Solution:		As part of the Battle of France on the Western Front, the Battle of Dunkirk was the defence and evacuation to Britain of British and other Allied forces in Europe from 26 May to 4 June 1940. After the Phoney War, the Battle of France began in earnest on 10 May 1940.

questions.Question: The violent Mappilas stormed the bungalow of the District Magistrate . . . . . . and murdered him in 1855
questions.solution: Solution:		At about 9 p.m. on the evening of 11 September 1855 Conolly was attacked and killed at the Collector's Residence at West Hill Bungalow, Calicut by a small group of Mappilas. Conolly was buried in what is now Conolly Park, near South Beach Road; the headstone of his tomb was moved to the premises of the C.S.I. St. Mary's English Church, Calicut in 1997.

questions.Question: The Treaty of Surat was in the year __________
questions.solution: Solution:		The Treaty of Surat (6 March 1775) was a treaty by which Raghunathrao, one of the claimants to the throne of the Peshwa, agreed to cede Salsette and Bassein Fort to the English, in consideration of being himself restored to Poona. The military operations that followed are known as the First Anglo-Maratha War.

questions.Question:
Assertion (A): British excluded the Indian middle and upper classes from the high administrative and military posts.
Reason (R): Many of the traditional zamindars lost their zamindaris to the new class of urban-based absentee landlords
questions.optionA: Both A and R is true and R is the correct explanation of A
questions.optionB: Both A and R is true but R is not a correct explanation of A
questions.optionC: A is true but R is false
questions.optionD: A is false but R is true
questions.solution: Solution:		Many of them lost their zamindaris to the new class of urban-based absentee landlords due to the introduction of the zamindari or the new class of urban-based absentee landlords due to the introduction of zamindari or the permanent settlement, and the strict manner of revenue collection by the British.

questions.Question: In 1877 the entrance age to ICS was reduced from 21 to __________
questions.solution: Solution:		In 1877 the entrance age to ICS was reduced from 21 to 19.

questions.Question: Charles Wood's Despatch__________
questions.solution: Solution:		Sir Charles Wood, the President of the Board of Control, had an important effect on spreading English learning and female education in India. When in 1855 he sent a despatch to Lord Dalhousie, the then Governor-General of India.Wood suggested that primary colleges must adopt vernacular languages, high schools must adopt Anglo verncular language and on college level English medium for education. This is known as Wood's despatch. Vocational and women's education were not stressed upon.

questions.Question: The Indian naval mutiny against the British took place in the year
questions.solution: Solution:		The Naval Ratings mutiny took place in 1946. Basically, it started as the sailors were dissatisfied with the food they were given. This snowballed into a mutiny against British rule. The mutiny started in Bombay Dock.

questions.Question: The land was owned by temples known as __________
questions.solution: Solution:		In Kerala, temples are managed by Devaswom Board,which comes under the government of Kerala.

questions.Question: Dyer was __________ by the Government of Britain
questions.solution: Solution:		After the Punjab disturbances, O'Dyer was relieved of his office by the government of Britain.

questions.Question: The capital of British India was transferred from Calcutta to Delhi in the year
questions.solution: Solution:		Delhi was officially announced as the capital of British Raj by the then-Emperor George V, on December 12, 1911. The capital was shifted from Calcutta as Delhi was the financial and political seat of many earlier empires and was located closer to the geographical center of India.

questions.Question: The transfer of Government from the 'Company' to the 'Crown' was pronounced by Lord Canning (November 1, 1858) at
questions.solution: Solution:		To declare the assumption of the Government of India by the crown a Durbar was held at Allahabad on November 1, 1858, by the Viceroy Lord Canning. Queen`s proclamation was read by Lord Canning. As per the proclamation, the administration of India came into the direct hands of British Government.

questions.Question: The decisive battle of the third Carnatic War was waged between the French and the British at
questions.solution: Solution:		The Battle of Wandiwash was a decisive battle in India during the Seven Years' War. The Count de Lally's army, burdened by a lack of naval support and funds, attempted to regain the fort at Vandavasi, now in Tamil Nadu. This was the Third Carnatic War fought between the French and the British.

questions.Question:
Which of the following statement (s) is/are correct related to the Charter Act of 1793?
I. Renewed the Charter of the Company for 20 more years.
II. Regulated the finances of the Company.
III. Lay down that the salaries of the Board of Control and their staffs were to be paid from the British revenues.
IV. Prohibited the Commander-in-Chief from being a member of the Governor General's Council
questions.solution: Solution:		The statements that are correct related to the Charter Act of 1793 were Renewed the Charter of the Company for 20 more years. Regulated the finances of the Company. Prohibited the Commander-in-Chief from being a member of the Governor General's Council.

questions.Question: The correct Chronological order in which the British established their trading centre in the places mentioned below is

questions.Question: Punjab was annexed to the British empire during the reign of Governor General
questions.solution: Solution:		During the reign of Dalhousie East India Company annexed Punjab in 1849. questions.Question: Who of the following Governor General is associated with Subsidiary Alliance System?
questions.solution: Solution:		The Subsidiary Alliance System was “Non-Intervention Policy” used by Lord Wellesley who was the Governor-General (1798-1805) to establish British Empire in India. questions.Question: The East India Association was founded by __________ in 1866
questions.solution: Solution:		The East India Association was founded by Dadabhai Naoroji in 1866, in collaboration with Indians and retired British officials in London. questions.Question: Who defeated the Spanish Armada?

questions.Question: Who was the first Governor General of India?

questions.Question:
Arrange the following in chronological order:
I. Viceroy Lytton
II. Viceroy Mayo
III. Viceroy Lansdowne
IV. Viceroy Linlithgow
questions.solution: Solution:		Viceroy Mayo- Richard Southwell Bourke, 6th Earl of Mayo, KP, GCSI, PC, styled Lord Naas between 1842 and 1867, called Lord Mayo in India, was a statesman, Viceroy of India and prominent member of the British Conservative Party from Dublin, Ireland. Viceroy Lytton- Robert Bulwer-Lytton, 1st Earl of Lytton GCB GCSI GCIE PC was an English statesman, Conservative politician, and poet. He served as Viceroy of India between 1876 and 1880 - during his tenure as which Queen Victoria was proclaimed Empress of India - and as British Ambassador to France from 1887 to 1891. Viceroy Lansdowne- Henry Charles Keith Petty-Fitzmaurice, 5th Marquess of Lansdowne, KG, GCSI, GCMG, GCIE, PC was a British statesman who served successively as the fifth Governor General of Canada, Viceroy of India, Secretary of State for War, and Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs. Viceroy Linlithgow- Victor Alexander John Hope, 2nd Marquess of Linlithgow, KG, KT, FRSE, GCSI, GCIE, OBE was a British Unionist politician, agriculturalist and colonial administrator. He served as Governor-General and Viceroy of India from 1936 to 1943. He was usually referred to simply as Linlithgow.

questions.Question: The Hindu Widows Remarriage Act __________

questions.Question: As per 'August Offer' the British objective for India was __________
questions.solution: Solution:		The August Offer was a proposal made by the British government in 1940 promising the expansion of the Executive Council of the Viceroy of India to include more Indians, the establishment of an advisory war council, giving full weight to minority opinion, and the recognition of Indians' right to frame their own constitution (after the end of the war). The Congress rejected the August Offer. Nehru said, “Dominion status concept is dead as a door nail.” Gandhi said that the declaration had widened the gulf between the nationalists and the British rulers.

questions.Question: Who had, while fasting in the prison, written to the British governor, The individual must die so that the nation may live. Today, I must die so that India may win freedom and glory?
questions.solution: Solution:		Jatin Das, while fasting in the prison, written to the British governor, The individual must die so that the nation may live. Today, I must die so that India may win freedom and glory.

questions.Question: During the period of which Governor General Viceroy was the Indian Civil Service introduced?
questions.solution: Solution:		Cornwallis realised that in order to consolidate the British rule in India, it was very important to organise the civil services. Civil Services was started by Lord Cornwallis and hence he is called the “Father of Indian Civil Service”.

questions.Question: Who said that he had not become His Majesty's first Minister to preside over the liquidation of the British Empire?
questions.solution: Solution:		Churchill said that the Charter did not apply to India, for he had 'not become His Majesty's first minister to preside over the liquidation of the British empire'.

questions.Question: Which of the following authorised the British Government to imprison any person without trial and conviction in a court of law
questions.solution: Solution:		As per the Rowlatt act the govemment had the power to arrest any person without showing any reason, the acts were threat to the civil liberties. Later, this act became the reason for occurrence of Jallianwala Bagh Tragedy.

questions.Question: The Seven Years' War (1756-1763) resulted in the defeat of the__________ forces
questions.solution: Solution:		In 1756, the British formally declared war against France. In addition, Spanish attempts to aid France in the Americas had failed, and France also suffered defeats against British forces in India. The Seven Years' War ended with the signing of the treaties of Hubertusburg and Paris in February 1763.

questions.Question: India became independent during the vice royalty of
questions.solution: Solution:		Lord Mountbatten: Last Viceroy of India (1947-1948) Lord Mountbatten served as last Viceroy of India from 12 February 1947 – 15 August 1947; and then first Governor General of Free India from 15 August 1947 – 21 June 1948. During his tenure, India got independence in the form of two dominions of India Pakistan.

questions.Question: Which Governor General had entertained Ranjit Singh with great honour at Ropar?
questions.solution: Solution:		 Governor General William Bentinck had entertained Ranjit Singh with great honour at Ropar.

questions.Question: Which of the following statement is not correct about the provisions of the Government of India Act,1858?
questions.optionA: The Queen's Principal Secretary of State received the powers and duties of the Company's Court of Directors
questions.optionB: A council of fifteen members was appointed to assist the Secretary of State for India
questions.optionC: For all the communications between Britain and India, the Secretary of State became the real channel
questions.optionD: All the above statements are incorrect
questions.solution: Solution:		The Government of India Act 1858 was an Act of the Parliament of the United Kingdom passed on August 2, 1858. Its provisions called for the liquidation of the British East India Company (who had up to this point been ruling British India under the auspices of Parliament) and the transference of its functions to the British Crown.

questions.Question: Which of the following is not the provision of the government of India Act, 1858?
questions.optionA: India was to be governed in the Queen's name
questions.optionB: The Queen's Principal Secretary of State received the powers and duties of the Company's Court of Directors
questions.optionC: Provision for the creation of an Indian Civil Service under the control of the Secretary of State
questions.optionD: The British Parliament was empowered to appoint a Governor-General and the Governors of the Presidencies
questions.solution: Solution:		The Government of India Act 1858 was an Act of the Parliament of the United Kingdom passed on August 2, 1858. Its provisions called for the liquidation of the British East India Company (who had up to this point been ruling British India under the auspices of Parliament) and the transference of its functions to the British Crown.

questions.Question: Who was the prime minister of Britain at the time of commencement of the Government of India Act, 1858?
questions.solution: Solution:		Lord Palmerston was the prime minister of Britain at the time of commencement of the Government of India Act, 1858.

questions.Question: Who was the monarch of Britain at the time of commencement of the Government of India Act, 1858?
questions.solution: Solution:		 In August 1858, the British parliament passed an act that set an end to the rule of the company. The control of the British government in India was transferred to the British crown. At this time, Victoria was the queen of Britain.

questions.Question: Which of the following Government of India Act/Indian Council Act brought three separate presidencies (Madras, Bombay and Bengal) into a common system?
questions.solution: Solution:		The Act for the first time introduced local representation in the Indian government. Rule of company in India ended and the rule of Crown started. The three presidencies (Madras, Bombay and Bengal) were three separate presidencies brought into a common system.

questions.Question: "Treaty of Rajpurghat" was signed on December 25, 1805 between Holkar and __________
questions.solution: Solution:		Yashwantrao was the last to sign a treaty with the British, on 24 December 1805 at a place called Rajpur Ghat on the bank of Beas River. The treaty was named 'The Treaty of Peace and Amity between the British Government and Yashwantrao Holkar.'

questions.Question: The llbert Bill controversy during the period of Lord Ripon exposed the racial bitterness of the British and united the Indians
questions.solution: Solution:		British subjects in 1873 had been exempted from trial by Indian magistrates, and in cases involving death or transportation they could only be tried by a high court. But by 1883 the viceroy, Lord Ripon, proposed to make British subjects amenable to sessions courts, over which Indians were now senior enough in the civil service to preside. This proposal as embodied in the Ilbert Bill provoked furious protests, especially among the Calcutta (Kolkata) European business community and the Bengal indigo planters, and there was covert sympathy from many officials.

questions.Question: The Peshwaship was abolished by the British at the time of Peshwa
questions.solution: Solution:		Baji Rao II (10 January, 1775 – 28 January, 1851) was the last Peshwa of the Maratha Empire, and governed from 1795 to 1818. He was installed as a puppet ruler by the Maratha nobles, whose growing power prompted him to flee his capital Pune and sign the Treaty of Bassein (1802) with the British. The last Peshwa was Baji Rao-II. Duringhrs reign the peshwa ship was abolished by the British Government (Lord Harding-I, third Anglo Maratha battle).

questions.Question: Who among the following had been the leader of a number of anti-British revolts in Sambalpur?
questions.solution: Solution:		By virtue of the Doctrine of Lapse, Lord Dalhousie annexed Sambalpur in 1849, as Narayan Singh had no male successor to succeed him. During the uprising of 1857 the sepoys set Surendra Sai and his brother Udyant Sai free. The resistance to British continued in Sambalpur under the leadership of Surendra Sai.

questions.Question: On imprisonment in 1908 by the British, Bal Gangadhar Tilak was in
questions.solution: Solution:		Bal Gangadhar Tilak was imprisoned in 1908 to Mandalay for six years. Tilak criticise the Britishers in his newspaper, under a article name 'Bharat ki Durdasha' and this became the reason for his imprisonment.

questions.Question: Madras was returned by the French to the British in 1748 by the Treaty of
questions.solution: Solution:		Madras was returned by the French to the British in 1748 by the Treaty of Aix-la-Chapelle.

questions.Question: Which of the following counterpart of British in the Treaty of Salbai?
questions.solution: Solution:		The Treaty of Salbai was signed on 17 May 1782, by representatives of the Maratha Empire and the British East India Company after long negotiations to settle the outcome of the First Anglo-Maratha War. David Anderson concluded the Treaty of Salbai on behalf of the East India Company.

questions.Question: The master stroke of Lord Wellesley to establish British paramountcy in India was
questions.solution: Solution:		The master stroke of Lord Wellesley to establish British paramountcy in India was Subsidiary Alliance.

questions.Question: In what way did the early nationalists undermine the moral foundations of the British rule with great success?
questions.optionA: By their agitation for Constitutional reforms
questions.optionC: By seeking foreign help against the British
questions.optionD: By seeking the support of the Indians living abroad
questions.solution: Solution:		The very conditions of British rule helped the growth of national sentiment. Roy was the first Indian leader to start an agitation for political reforms in India. There is a moral evil which, if anything, is even greater.

questions.Question: On account of severe British repression the Civil Disobedience movement was again suspended In July 1933 and people were asked to offer Satyagraha
questions.solution: Solution:		On account of severe British repression the Civil Disobedience movement was again suspended In July 1933 and people were asked to offer Satyagraha individually.

questions.Question: Who was Lord Morley?
questions.solution: Solution:		Lord Morley became secretary of state for India in Henry Campbell-Bannerman's Cabinet of 1905.

questions.Question: The Non-Cooperation Movement under Gandhi was in full swing during the Viceroyalty of
questions.solution: Solution:		The Non-Cooperation Movement under Gandhi was in full swing during the Viceroyalty of Reading.

questions.Question: Which of the following charter act ended the monopoly of trade of east India Company with china and sea route also?
questions.solution: Solution:		The Charter act of 1813 ended the monopoly of the East India Company in India, however the company's monopoly in trade with china and trade in tea was remained intact. The charter act of 1813, for the first time explicitly defined the constitutional position of the British territories in India.

questions.Question: Queen Victoria's famous proclamation, transferring authority from the East India Company to the Crown , was made from
questions.solution: Solution:		Queen Victoria's famous proclamation, A Royal Durbar was held at Allahabad in November 1, 1858. A proclamation was issued by Queen Victoria. It was read at the Durbar by Lord Canning, who was the last Governor General and the first Viceroy of India.

questions.Question: An ambassador of the British King James I, who secured favourable privileges for the East India Company from Emperor Jahangir, was
questions.solution: Solution:		From 1615 to 1618, he was ambassador to the court at Agra, India, of the Great Mughal Ruler, Jahangir. The principal object of the mission was to obtain protection for the East India Company`s factory at Surat. At the Mughal court, Roe allegedly became a favorite of Jahangir and may have been his drinking partner.

questions.Question: In which region did Birsa Munda operate against the British?
questions.solution: Solution:		Birsa Munda was a great tribal leader belonging to the Munda Adivasi, the movement operate against Britishin Chhota Nagpur (Jharkhand) region.

questions.Question: The single biggest item of British capital investment in India was
questions.solution: Solution:		The single biggest item of British capital investment in India was Railways.

questions.Question: Which of the Act made the governor of Bengal as Governor General of India?
questions.solution: Solution:		Governor-General of Bengal was made Governor-General of India through the Charter Act of 1833.

questions.Question: British Crown assumed sovereignty over Indian from the East Indian Company in the year
questions.solution: Solution:		The government of India Act (1858) also known as the act for Good Government of India transferred the power to the British crown from East India company.

questions.Question: Who was the Viceroy at the time of Quit India Movement?
questions.solution: Solution:		Lord Linlithgow (1936 – 1944) was the viceroy of India during Quit India Movement. The Quit India Movement (also known as the August Movement) was a civil disobedience movement launched by Mahatma Gandhi on August 8,1942 in Mumbai for complete independence

questions.Question: Sir Thomas Roe came to India with a letter from the British Monarch
questions.solution: Solution:		This event also started the process of transforming the British East India Company from a group of merchants, to an organization with military force. In 1614, King James I of England sent a diplomat, Sir Thomas Roe, to visit the Mughal emperor, Jahangir, and negotiate a trade treaty.

questions.Question: Subsidiary Alliance was introduced by __________
questions.solution: Solution:		The Subsidiary Alliance System was "Non-Intervention Policy" used by Lord Wellesley who was the Governor-General (1798-1805) to establish British Empire in India. According to this system, every ruler in India had to accept to pay a subsidy to the British for the maintenance of British army.

questions.Question: The policy of Doctrine of lapse was introduced by __________
questions.solution: Solution:		The doctrine of lapse was an annexation policy applied by the British East India Company in India until 1858. The policy is most commonly associated with Lord Dalhousie, who was the Governor General of the East India Company in India between 1848 and 1856.

questions.Question:
Assertion (A): On 25th April, 1809, the Treaty of Amritsar was signed between Ranjit Singh and East India Company.
Reason (R): Ranjit Singh wanted to increase the realm of his empire with the help of the company
questions.optionA: Both A and R is true and R is the correct explanation of A
questions.optionB: Both A and R is true but R is not a correct explanation of A
questions.optionC: A is true but R is false
questions.optionD: A is false but R is true
questions.solution: Solution:		Treaty of Amritsar (1809) The Treaty of Amritsar of 1809 was an agreement between the British East India Company and Ranjit Singh, the Sikh leader who founded the Sikh empire.

questions.Question: Who put on the statute book two obnoxious measures the Vernacular press Act and the Indian Arms Act
questions.solution: Solution:		Lytton put on the statute book two obnoxious measures— the vernacular press Act and Indian Arms Act. Lytton' s unpopular acts provoked a great storm of opposition in the country and led to the organisation of various political associations for carrying an anti-Government propaganda in the country.

questions.Question: The Indian Civil Service Act was passed during the Viceroyalty of
questions.solution: Solution:		Lord Canning (1858–62): The Indian Councils Act of 1862 was passed, which proved to be a landmark in the constitutional history of India.

questions.Question: The Ancient Monuments Preservation Act was passed during the viceroyalty of
questions.solution: Solution:		One of the most remarkable acts passed during the times of Lord Curzon was the Ancient Monuments Preservation Act of 1904. This act made any injury to the protected monuments an offence punishable under the law.

questions.Question: When did the British Govt. start ruling India directly?
questions.solution: Solution:		After Sepoy Mutiny rule established in 1857, British govt. started ruling over India, Governor general became the Viceroy and Lord Canning became the last Governor General and first Viceroy.

questions.Question: Diu was the colony of the __________
questions.solution: Solution:		Daman and Diu were once part of a combined union territory along with Goa (a Konkani-speaking region), before Goa became a state in 1987. The use of Portuguese, which was the territory's official language during the colonial period, is in decline and relegated to home use.

questions.Question: According to the terms of the treaty of Srirangapattanam, . . . . . . was ceded to the British
questions.solution: Solution:		According to the terms of the treaty of Srirangapattanam, Malabar was ceded to the British.

questions.Question: The Treaty between Ranjit Singh and the British was signed at
questions.solution: Solution:		Treaty of Amritsar, (April 25, 1809), pact concluded between Charles T. Metcalfe, representing the British East India Company, and Ranjit Singh, head of the Sikh kingdom of Punjab. The British wanted a defensive treaty against the French and control of Punjab to the Sutlej River.

questions.Question: When the East India Company came into existence, England was ruled by the__________
questions.solution: Solution:		When the East India Company came into existence, England was ruled by the Stuarts.

questions.Question: __________ , the viceroy of India decided to partition Bengal for administrative purposes, creating a new province of East Bengal and Assam, with a population of 31 million people and with its capital at Dhaka
questions.solution: Solution:		Lord Curzon, the viceroy of India decided to partition Bengal for administrative purposes, creating a new province of East Bengal and Assam, with a population of 31 million people and with its capital at Dhaka.

questions.Question: Indian Mutiny began in __________
questions.solution: Solution:		The Indian Rebellion of 1857 is also called the Indian Mutiny, the Sepoy Mutiny, North India's First War of Independence or North India's first struggle for independence. It began on 10 May 1857 at Meerut, as a mutiny of sepoys of the British East India Company's army.

questions.Question: Robert Clive, the Governor General of the __________
questions.solution: Solution:		Major-General Robert Clive, 1st Baron Clive, KB, FRS, also known as Clive of India, Commander-in-Chief of British India, was a British officer and privateer who established the military and political supremacy of the East India Company in Bengal.

questions.Question: Throughout the 19th century intermittent uprisings occurred in Malabar, especially in the __________ and Valluvanad taluks.Twenty two such riots were reported from different parts of Malabar
questions.solution: Solution:		Throughout the 19th century intermittent uprisings occurred in Malabar, especially in the Ernad and Valluvanad taluks.Twenty two such riots were reported from different parts of Malabar.

questions.Question: During their rule the British persuaded or forced cultivators in Bengal to grow__________
questions.solution: Solution:		Britisher invested in agriculture to fulfil the demand of raw materials required for industries in Britain. So, British persuaded or forced cultivator in Bengal to grow Jute (it also known as golden fibre).

questions.Question: What did the Rowlatt Act, 1919 empower the British government to do
questions.optionB: Shut down any industrial unit at will
questions.optionC: Extend the period of imprisonment for Indians
questions.optionD: Detain a person for any duration without a trial
questions.solution: Solution:		Rowlatt Acts, (February 1919), legislation passed by the Imperial Legislative Council, the legislature of British India. The acts allowed certain political cases to be tried without juries and permitted internment of suspects without trial.

questions.Question: In 1614 Sir Thomas Roe was instructed by __________ to visit the court of Jahangir, the Mughal emperor of India
questions.solution: Solution:		In 1614 Sir Thomas Roe was instructed by James I to visit the court of Jahangir, the Moghul emperor of Hindustan to arrange a commercial treaty and to secure for the East India Company sites for commercial agencies. Sir Thomas was successful, and though the Great Moghul Jahangir was contemptuous of the presents sent him by James I, he sent him a remarkably polite letter.

questions.Question: When were Morley-Minto reforms taken place?
questions.solution: Solution:		The Indian Councils Act 1909, commonly known as the Morley-Minto Reforms (or as the Minto-Morley Reforms), was an Act of the Parliament of the United Kingdom that brought about a limited increase in the involvement of Indians in the governance of British India.

questions.Question: The writers of the East India Company had their training in the college at __________ in England
questions.solution: Solution:		The writers of the East India Company had their training in the college at Haileybury in England.

questions.Question: Gandhiji's famous Quit India movement call to the British was given in
questions.solution: Solution:		Gandhiji launched Quit India Movement on 8th August 1942 in Bombay session of congress. It is also known as August revolutoion.

questions.Question: Lord __________ is regarded to have been the father of local self-government in India
questions.solution: Solution:		Lord Ripon is known as Father of Local Self Government in India. This was not enacted by any act, it was a resolution that was passed in 1882.

questions.Question: Which war lord is also known as 'little corporal'
questions.solution: Solution:		Napoleon Bonaparte war lord is also known as 'little corporal'.

questions.Question: Who among of the following was the Viceroy of India when Indian University Act, 1904 was passed?
questions.solution: Solution:		During the time period of Indian University act,1904 Lord Curzon was the Viceroy of India.

questions.Question: When the Simon Commission visited India the Viceroy was
questions.solution: Solution:		Simon Commission had visited India on April 3, 1926 Lord Irwin was appointed 30th Viceroy and Governor-General of India. In 1927, British government appointed a commission under the chairmanship of Sir John Simon.

questions.Question: Who was the Viceroy when the Jallianwala Bagh Massacre took place?
questions.solution: Solution:		Lord Chelmsford was the Viceroy of India when Jallianwala Bagh Massacre took place on 13 April 1919.

questions.Question: Seringapatnam was the capital of __________
questions.solution: Solution:		In 1767 Maratha Peshwa Madhavrao defeated both Hyder Ali and Tipu Sultan and entered Srirangapatna, the capital of Mysore.

questions.Question:
Consider the following on the chronology of appointment of Viceroys
I. Reading
II. Irwin
III. Wellingdon
IV. Linlithgow
questions.solution: Solution:		The following on the chronology of appointment of Viceroys were Reading, Irwin, Wellingdon and Linlithgow.
